text: [Music]
hey guys it's angel today I'm going to
show you how to make these delicious red
bean cakes now imagine we call these
home doping and in Taiwanese we oddly
enough call these Java and Bing which is
basically car wheel cake I don't even
know why they call them that but
supposedly they look like car wheels
which to me sounds really unappetizing
but trust me when I say they are so so
good now what makes this recipe really
unique are the cast iron pants that the
wheel cakes are cooked in and lucky for
us tada I have one of these cast iron
pans with me today that I brought back
from Taiwan and don't worry if you guys
don't have one of these pans at home
because if you're interested in making
this recipe there are actually a lot of
options online so I'll leave a couple
options in the video description and if
you guys want to see it and hear a
little bit more about this pan that I
got from Taiwan I'll do a little mini
unboxing at the end of this video so
with that I'm super excited to share
this recipe with you guys so let's jump
right in and get started first let's
start with the ingredients for the
batter will need 1 cup of cake flour 1/2
a cup of organic cane sugar 2 large eggs
a splash of vanilla extract 1 teaspoon
each of oil and baking powder 1/2 a cup
of filtered water and finally for the
filling some sweetened red bean paste to
make the batter add all the dry
ingredients into a mixing bowl and sift
those together before adding the eggs
and the rest of the wet ingredients
making sure not to forget the vanilla
extract because that's going to make
everything smell and taste really good
next gently mix everything until the
batter is smooth and well combined and
just to be on the safe side I like to
pour mine through a strainer as I
transfer it to an easy pour container
finally optional but highly recommended
you can cover and store the batter in
the fridge for at least an hour or
overnight to let any air bubbles settle
and rise to the top when you're ready to
make your wheel cakes take out your
special pan and preheat at a low
temperature so things don't burn next
with some neutral flavored oil brush the
inside and corners of the molds before
using now we're going to make the top
halfs of our wheel cakes first by
pouring the batter about 40 percent full
we'll want to let those cook for about 2
minutes as we give them a slight head
start on cooking next pour the batter
for the bottom halves about 50% full let
that batter continue to cook and develop
an edge crest before putting a small
scoop of red bean filling in the center
then allow the bottoms to heat up for
another minute or two while we check
back on our tops using a long toothpick
or a tool with a sharp point
gently lift to see if the top crust is a
golden brown when it's ready pour some
additional batter on top of the red bean
filling to act as the glue then gently
flip and press the tops onto the fresh
batter to make our wheel cakes whole let
that continue to cook for another few
minutes until both sides are golden
brown you can also flip them over again
if you'd like now don't worry if they
aren't perfect and maybe even slightly
burnt the first few times you try to
make these because they'll still taste
really good anyways and that's what
makes them unique right when you're done
it's best to serve them freshly cooked
and hot off the grill
so that's how you make these red bean
cakes I wish you guys were here so you
could smell this in my kitchen right now
my kitchen smells amazing it's like
going into an ice cream shop and
smelling freshly made waffles cones mmm
smells like that you guys know what I'm
talking about
I'm angel thank you guys so much for
watching I hope I inspired you to make
this dessert recipe at home and I will
see you guys soon bye
okay so just in case you guys want to
know where I got my pan from I got this
on my last trip to Taiwan it's a cast
iron pan so it's pretty heavy I actually
got this in a DIY shop in Taipei it was
a little bit hard to find and it wasn't
near the subway so I actually had to
take a cab I actually took an uber there
and they only have one of these left
they had two different types of pans for
making these wheel cakes they had this
type which is a smaller one with the cat
and the koala shape and they had the one
that is on Amazon which I will post a
link in the video description but I had
a choice between those two the Amazon
one that one was bigger this one's
smaller they both had different designs
but I really wanted the koala and the
cat design so I ended up getting this
the one caveat is he might have noticed
in my video that I was not using this
particular mold up here in the upper
left and that is because there's a
little defect I don't know if you can
see that but it basically is a little
defect in the cat face and they didn't
really want to sell this to me so I had
to ask them to sell it to me they gave
me a little bit of a discount it ended
up being about 25 dollars 25 US dollars
but I really really wanted this cuz I
thought it was so unique with the
characters in addition to this I got two
other tools a little oil spatula or oil
brush tool which is super helpful and I
got a little poker thingy which you
definitely need when making these wheels
all of these came in a little box like
this and apparently this company makes a
similar mold for takoyaki x' as well and
those are Japanese octopus balls in case
you're wondering so again if you can
find this mold and you like it great
definitely this is an option I did not
see this online on Amazon so if any of
you have found this online please post
in the comments below so everybody can
see but I did see the other one that I
saw at the DIY shop and that one again
is a little bit bigger so that is it
mini unboxing
